I'm pretty sure the "tests" that were conducted fail to remove a lot of reasoning behind the actions of the subjects. In order to even attempt to see whether something changes a person's behavior you really need a baseline of his behavior without the added circumstances that should influence him/her. I would under no circumstance let the kid take the blame, but I probably wouldn't end in that situation either. Furthermore I can totally see the kid getting away with it if he took the blame whereas a grown up would have to accept the consequences of their action which might make them anxious to speak up to not take the blame for something that, probably in their mind, they see as an honest mistake(what are the odds of a  thief attempting to take advantage of a person they've no idea can tell they shouldn't be there). You need to know the tendency of that person to take the blame and you need to be sure that in their mind whoever takes the responsibility of the theft it will have the same impact on their life.

Wait wait wait….but this doesn’t seem to take things like race or gender into account??

A person of color may rightly feel more endangered, especially once things are escalated to include security and mentions of police. A 12-year-old white boy is going to be treated VASTLY differently by law enforcement than an adult man of color, and it would be insanely unfair not to take that into account. You can’t take it as a mark against someone’s moral character when they know they could very literally end up in a life threatening situation vs a child who will almost certainly be given a slap on the wrist and sent home.

Likewise, someone with children may be much less likely to let a child take the for them, as it’s much easier for them to relate to the position both the child AND his mom will be put in as a result. A man might be more likely to have the concept of “chivalry” imbedded into his upbringing. Also, the first experiment used a “homeless” man wearing military fatigues, which could imply (even subconsciously) that this man was one of the many, many homeless vets that are a recognized issue in this country; that’s also a significant possible factor.

I love this show bc it shows such interesting demonstrations of behavior spanning diverse backgrounds, but it’s not okay to do it without discussing all the factors that could be at play. Even when Michael does urge us not to leap to conclusions about human morals after viewing these types of episode, people still will. He and the writers/producers (if applicable) have a responsibility to their audience to PREFACE these kinds of experiment with at least a mention of the types of factors at play, BEFORE folks have already seen the experiment play out and come to their own conclusions.

You guys are way too forgiving (or naive and gullible). This was a clear cut case of doing the obvious right or wrong thing. There can be no rationalizing it away.

There are three things you can do with money.
You can:
1. Spend it,
2. Save it, or
3. Give it away.
—> Nothing in this world is more gratifying than giving money away.
☆ Giving it to people in need, while asking nothing in return, is all the more gratifying.

Kind of odd how you scored the participants on their giving — and it likely skewed your study's insights into moral licensing.
▪︎ Giving $1 is hardly a good deed and certainly doesn't qualify your participants as being a "good person." Giving $1 is the minimum cost of getting rid of an annoyance.
▪︎ I think that genuinely helping someone today starts at $20 minimum, and only increases from there based on age, occupation, income, net worth, and special life circumstances.
▪︎ Giving money to a person in need really does require the giver to incur some financial pain.
▪︎ A person who is willing to endure some pain to help another who they don't know and may be derelict in some respect likely constitutes one as a "good person," or more accurately a compassionate person.

There're so many things that feel wrong in this. Like how some deeds count more than others and how opening the door to the guy can be seen as a good deed. The guy does say his hands are full. They didn't check if he had a keycard, but that doesn't matter. They realize afterwards that they messed up. All the people who opened the door technically already did a good deed by opening it.

The money part is also really stupid. If the ratio is 100 : 1, of course people will give 1$. It's not your 100$. It boarderline feels like you're scamming them at that point. I wouldn't call that a good deed. Maybe some people would. But here lies the problem. It depends on the people and it breaks their whole experience.

And the gravity of the situation is also a factor. The dude that confessed at the start doesn't know what he's getting into. If you don't confess right away, the situation escalates so much that it gets to a point where it's not about moral licensing anymore. It's more about not getting into trouble yourself. You're not commiting a "bad deed" by not talking. You're actually commiting a "good deed" by talking. It's 2 different things. Standing up for the kid takes you out of your confort zone. I feel there's a lot of varibales going into these experiments that are not really adressed. In the first one about cleaning one could argue that the "best" option morally is to NOT help clean. By helping to clean you are in fact giving away free labor to the municipality or city or whoever really has the obligation to keep the park clean. The fact that there is this much trash in the park means that either the ones tasked with keeping the park clean are neglecting their duties or are in fact not given adequate resources to do so. This second alternative could probably be used in a negotiation or such between the park workers and their employer as in: "Look, you need to hire more people. We can't manage this amount of work in the time you're paying us".

In the second experiment you could also argue that putting the blame on a white kid will have waaaay lower repercussions for that kid than it would have for an adult black male. Also, the fact that this kid is there with his parent most likely mens that this parent has the time to not be working at that time which in turn means she's probably not flipping burgers at McDonalds but rather has a cushy office job where she has a high degree of control over her working hours which in turn also means she probably makes a good salary and has other nice perks going with the job. All in all the this kid will most likely be fine. Worst case scenario his parents will have to play for the merchandise stolen which will most likely not even make a dent in their economy.

I often see this with the field of psychology in academics- they treat people like exact copies of each other, failing to adress the inherent differences in how society treats people based on their class, race, gender etc. And in turn how people try to navigate these inequalities.

This episode was very interesting in demonstrating the difference between people's actions and their beliefs about how they would act. But it didn't demonstrate or relate to moral licensing at all. The first example with the cleanup and the homeless man was totally off the mark, since the subsequent "good deed" being measured was by no means clearly a "good deed". There are many arguments for why giving money to a homeless person, especially if they appear capable, could in fact be enabling behavior and reasoned to be a bad thing, irrespective of prior good deeds. Also, it is conflating NOT doing a good act (if we accept the premise that giving money to a homeless person is good) with doing a BAD act. Moral licensing is specifically describing a person allowing themselves to do a bad thing because of accumulated "good credit", not "using up" their budget of good deeds.

The second experiment also failed to demonstrate moral licensing, but the design was better since allowing an innocent to take the blame would be more universally regarded as being a bad thing. However, and this is the key part, there is no way to establish causality between the donation and the subsequent "bad act". So much so, it is unclear if moral licensing is in fact a real phenomenon at all. Even the best possible study design here, which would include controls and large sample sizes, would at best be able to establish a statistically significant correlation between donating money and not allowing the child to take the blame. But there are a variety of explanations that could explain the correlation, so you could never establish that the prior act was the cause of the subsequent one. As Dr. Stanford concedes, social science is weary of taking post-hoc explanation at face value.

The "established" literature on moral licensing goes even further in this fundamental mistake. Examples like people consuming diet coke together with their hamburger and fries and being more likely to engage in self-indulgent behavior after doing something "good" are also overfitting the good deed as "causing" the bad one. There are alternative explanations that explain the correlation that are not in any way invalidated by the experiment. For example, a person has a certain minimum threshold of "good" deeds that they want to exhibit in order to be consistent with their self-identity. Hitting that bar earlier in the day means the threshold is satisfied. But then the inverse would also be true, which is that doing a bad deed makes one more likely to do a good deed later. In effect then, moral-licensing is a not a real phenomenon in the sense of bad deeds justifying good ones, so much as there is some average level of "good deeds performed over time" that are consistent with people's self-concepts, and depending on your measurement window you will see different sequences of good and bad behaviors.

I haven't found any convincing literature that establishes moral licensing as an actual experimentally verified cognitive bias and phenomenon. As is unfortunately common, lots of bad extrapolations and correlation/causation errors in social science rife with speculative explanations.

I understand the goal of these kinds of experiments but still, human behavior is immeasurably complex and these "experiments" try to validate oversimplifications.  There is always the bias of the individual, whether it be predicated on past experience, beliefs and worldviews, mood, how tired or hungry they are, etc. etc. among all the other idiosyncratic arbitrary human elements.  I myself on average almost never give money to homeless people, regardless of whether or not I've done anything "moral" prior.  Sometimes I just don't care because I'm in a bad mood.  Sometimes I don't feel good about what they might spend that money on.  Sometimes I feel like if they can stand out in southern summer heat and humidity all day (something I can't do due to chronic health issues), then they could do some damn work to earn the money.  And sometimes I actually feel sympathetic and based on their appearance and presentation, I actually feel like they NEED it, and I give money or I buy them food.  All of these internal conclusions being formed aren't always necessarily reliable or consistent, and that's the part of human psychology that can't be oversimplified.  I think when an individual really interprets that someone is in need of serious need of help, most people help, but determining that need is the tricky part.

I remember, when I was in seventh grade, I got into a situation where I accidentally got my best friend in trouble for something I accidentally made him do. At first, I just didn't do anything, because the teacher responded really quickly and I wasn't sure what to make of it - he got silent lunch (not that bad, but it's still a punishment that I figured he didn't deserve). I wanted to take the blame really badly.

I ended up telling the teacher while we were lined up outside to go to lunch. It was in the middle of the hallway, so anyone could've seen it, and I had a reputation as a kid who never got in trouble (so much so it was more likely for a teacher to wrongly accuse me than for me to have actually done something wrong), but despite all that, I shakily went up to the teacher and told her it was my fault, and that the punishment for my friend should be moved to me instead.

Without giving it much thought, she just said, "Okay," walked up to my friend and told him he was free, and that was the end of it. I received no punishment. It was really confusing and I was honestly a bit frightened during the confrontation, but I did a good thing, and that made me feel good. Still a bit confused why I wasn't punished though.

The point of me saying all this is that if, by chance, I was in that scenario where Noah was trying to take the blame for something I did, I'd probably refuse to let him take the blame (more strongly and confidently than before), since the scenarios are somewhat similar (I mean, 7th grade is literally when you're 12 going-on 13).

Then again, who knows? I wasn't thinking about losing a friend back then, and I don't remember my friend being very upset with me, but maybe that's why I acted that way. My only hope is that such wasn't the case.

Humans and apes have so different focus. It is like giving the same task to far-sighted and near-sighted persons. Im not convinced that the differences are due to the ability of speach sacrificing effective long therm memory. I believe that so much noise is going on in the back of our mind due to the modern living enviroment and our unhealthy habits that it is alone throws one off from focusing in a task like this. But even if we could live our every day life in a healthy environment free from the distraction, excercising meditation on regular basis we would still be very different in focus. My impression is that we are generally better at working with abstract symbols or with groups of abstract symbols in the first place, and this is why we were able to develop detailed communication. Also humans travel much bigger distances, our cordination in space seem to be better in larger dimensions, while monkeys and apes have to navigate in dense treetops where every step or grab can be dangerous.

I would be very interested to know what world views each of these people had, and would also suggest that not including that as data relevant to the results is a flaw in the experiment.   A person's personal view on morality can be greatly impacted by the worldview they adopt.   The sample size here isn't nearly large enough to draw any meaningful conclusions from, but if say the two people in the first experiment had both claimed to be Hindus, or both claimed to be Christians, or both claimed to be atheists, etc, and that world view was not represented in any of the other participants, it would be quite interesting to know that, and even if it had not led to any interesting results, this seems like such important data that anyone who was truly after meaningful results from the experiments would be compelled to collect it.

Hands down, the poorest episode in mind field. Too many variables involved in the last experiment.

The experiment is supposed to be meant to remove as many variables as possible to see the correlation between just the 2 variables of
1. Their donation
2. Not letting the kid take the blame

But it just keeps adding more and more variables. The fact that the situation was just confusing and trying to figure out why the kid took the blame had so much more to do, that the donation wouldn't even be in their minds, making the experiment pointless.

Other stuff like:

1. No, they wouldn't feel like they donated $100 if they just donated $1. That's ridiculous. They don't know how 1 would just become 100, doesn't even make sense, especially considering that the donation agreement at 14:32 that they signed is worded slightly confusingly. I'd be like "What even? Whatever, all I know is I'm giving $1".

2. For some subjects (17:46), the mom was not there in the room when the kid took the blame, whereas for some others (22:38), like the guy who owned up, the mom was there. That variable had a very big role to play, which mind field just either ignored or perhaps even did it purposely as no one actually owned up because of the confusing scenario, and they wanted to put someone who actually would own up in the episode. (I personally don't think so, coz it's Michael and he has a scientific mind, and I assume he understands the importance of unbiased experiments, but you never know considering that these are just episodes and it would be in their interest to make it more interesting.)

3. The kid and the mom were already there before the subjects showed up. So when the kid takes the blame, they might be wondering if the kid is even talking about the same guy as he might have let someone else in before they came. If anything, this just makes it slightly more confusing.

4. Maybe the subjects thought that the kid was somehow closely related to the people who worked there. So that's why he took the blame because he would know who all actually worked there. As time passed, calling the project head and the security and then taking the mom and the kid away would have given it away that the kid is not related to them, but it would be too late then because the situation had escalated a lot and the subjects would just be less likely to own up simply because they didn't own up earlier, irrespective of whether or not they made any donation.


Overall, a very bad episode because of the second experiment. I love mind field and I hope Michael performs more unbiased and lower variable experiments in the future episodes.

I have a different perspective on the moral licensing experiment in the park: in my hometown, when I was growing up, drunk homeless people used to hang around the package liquor on main street. Kids learn from an early age not to give them any spare change, because as soon as they had enough funds they would go and buy a bottle of any alcohol they could afford. If people wanted to help them out, they would buy them food… If they weren’t so drunk that they would waste it. So, growing up we learned that giving a homeless person money wasn’t necessarily a good deed, it might very well be enabling self-destructive behaviors.

Am I surprised that most people only act in kindness when others can observe it? Nope.
What I AM surprised about is all of the so called 'selfless' preaching constantly going on these days, along with all of these people on their high horses...literally telling others how to 'live' their lives. While they sit back and fail to follow along the same terms.
It's often the quiet ones who selflessly do the most, seeing no reason to be seen, nor heard. But purely because of what is in their heart.

The experiments don't seem to be controlled, there are many many extra factors involved (e.g. not opening the door seems like being an asshole or a bad deed itself), the studied populations are very small, there's no data about how likely the individuals were to do the good deeds outside the experiment, etc.

Long study short, this doesn't qualify as a scientific experiment. It is interesting nonetheless.

I also think one of the things to consider with the first phase of the experiment is that just about everyone who lives in a big city has a stance on giving money to the homeless and it doesn't matter what the stance actually is, they're going to think what they do is a positive thing. If they do not give money, it's because they think it's not good to give someone the money directly, instead they might donate to food banks or shelters with the justification that giving them cash directly, that money could be going to drugs/booze. The people that give money also see what they're doing as a positive because, well, there's someone who needs money and they give it. I'm not making a judgement call on either of these ways of thinking but having lived in a city where we all knew the local homeless population they seem to be the two major categories people fell into. And coming from a background as a heroin addict in recovery and having a few brushes with homelessness myself, I personally think it's probably better to give to charities that fund solutions to homelessness than giving someone the money directly. There are addicts that consider "flying a sign"(hanging out off an interstate off ramp with a 'homeless please help' sign) their job and as messed up as it sounds, I've known people to make money doing that than I was making at a legitimate job. So yeah, didn't mean to get sidetracked on a homelessness tangent, I just wanted to point out that because they feel their decision to give or not give is a 'moral' decision in either case, then it might not factor into their moral licensing

I think the second experiment would be much better if the blame was both on the child actor and a participant. There would no confusion about why the kid spoke up. From our collective experience as social creatures we know how much it costs to admit doing something wrong. We only do it because we're guilty or because we want to protect someone. Since the second option can't be true participants unconsciously assumed that the child is guilty in some way. Maybe they didn't see the kid doing something wrong, maybe the child knew something more about what truly happened

If both the actor and a participant did something bad together and only child admitted wrongdoing there would be no confusion why he spoke up because the participant saw it all happening in front of him / her

Obviously then, without a control group, it would be difficult to tell how much of the participants' behavior was a result of moral licensing and how much of it was being encouraged by the child's behavior to accept the responsibility for your own actions

The thing I just wanted to highlight is that 'licencing' is an interpretation rather than the name of tthe phenomenon (or rather a name that strongly suggests interpretation) which is a bit misleading. I see it as the energy balance problem: one could feel that enough energy has been put outbound and stop ongoing outgoing 'trafic' (could be a bad term as well). So there is no licencing in a sense of legislation, judicial or similar sense, rather it is like account balance management and when you really run out of fuel, bad things could happen and this subconscious mechanism is really vital, though in some cases it seems to overdo it's job. I don't get why people donate such a tiny amount. Maybe because I don't have much money at all, and almost never have cash, I like to make the most of those opportunities, but if you've got a bunch of ones, how the hell are you only giving the homeless guy one buck? And as for the charity thing, when are you ever going to get a 100 to 1 matching donation?! Unless you really need some of that money, you donate every single cent. I would probably ask if it's definitely going to be matched, and whether the company matching it took that into account, so it's fine to pass it all on, but clearing that, you have to give it all. (maybe ask if it's okay to give your own money, but make sure to say you understand if they can't allow that, because the company might have a hard limit, and might need to, even.)

Again, I imagine a significant part of that is, paradoxically, not regularly having enough money to deny to others. Money can buy a lot of happiness if you get to use it to do good, and a hit of metaphorical heroin, when you never get a hit, would be an unbelievable high.

Edit: In case it's not clear, I should say that most people can't always give money, even if they're not going to be short. There has to be a balance between saving, some pleasures, and sharing. Keeping yourself safe, happy, and healthy is just as important to society as keeping others safe, happy, and healthy.

Cool, but... hmm. I'm not convinced. Not giving money to a homeless person, or not keeping a kid from taking the blame for something we did are not explicitly bad things... they are passive stances. Another thing that makes me doubt is that it's very hard to keep a control group in this kind of experiment. So even if a subject behaves as expected, it's not immediately true that their first action influenced their second. For instance, somebody who cleaned and didn't give money afterwards might have not given money anyway if the cleaning part wasn't even part of the experiment, in which case their actions with the homeless person would be attributable to other things about them.

The main reason I think this way is that growing up my family and I would take vacations to Chicago, which was much different than my small suburban life in rural Indiana. How to make an experiment:
1. Convince participants to think it's something completely different.
2. Make it as realistic as possible so they believe the fake experiment is real.
3. Everyone is a paid actor.

STOP
and debrief everything.

Sorry man, but these experiments were terrible. For STARTERS, you need a control group in order for it to be a controlled experiment. Which these are now definitionally not, and do not fit not one standard for an experiment that does not require one. And even though the botched procedure renders your findings useless anyway, the execution was arguably even worse. There were a couple insultingly poor design flaws that skews the results so profoundly that it renders your control group-less experiment even more useless than it would’ve been anyway. Because not only is it lacking in credibility, but there’s about a 0% chance you’re experiment accurately reflects what precisely you’re trying to prove. FOR INSTANCE, the kid IMMEDIATELY going OUT OF HIS WAY to take the blame for seemingly no reason, and BEFORE the severity of it is even revealed, destroys your whole set up. Because it creates a “okay, sure, I’ll let him ACTIVELY take the blame if he’s hell bent on doing so” rationale to the subject. Ideally, you’d want the kid to RELUCTANTLY take the blame, not ACTIVELY do so on his own free will. Because the subject is inevitably going to think that, although it seems to them the kid is taking the blame for no reason, there must be SOME reason. Which means they may know something the subject does not, perhaps severity in punishment (although it could be any number of things), and that something is enough of an incentive for the more informed kid to take the blame. So to go against that, is to go against the kids own free will who actively WANTS to take the blame, for an unknown reason that’s apparently strong enough to compel the kid to take the blame. Doing precisely that does not indicate you have a surplus of moral credit, no, it indicates that you have a brain average to above average in the decision making department. A better experiment would have the subject opening the door, the thief stealing the shit, then, the subject being called OUT OF THE ROOM for something or another (paperwork, doesn’t really matter). Then, once finished, having the subject return to a sight of the kid being blamed for having opened the door, and the kid, at first, denying without throwing the subject under the bus, with a eventual, RELUCTANT admission of guilt, after having the severity of it spelled out for him. That would genuinely test the subject willingness to allow the kid to take the fall. But this? It is essentially an episode of “What Would You Do?” only not as good

The experiment in the first demonstration is flawed, because the two scenarios given to provide the test subjects the opportunity to display their natural moral licencing are too dissimilar. It's possible that a subject may be less inclined to a more physically labouring task like picking up rubbish as opposed to a much less physically labouring task like handing over some money, or vice versa simply based on their personal preference and choice. This means the outcome of the situations and the results of the experiment can be influenced by a variable other than moral licencing alone, which makes this experiment ineffective in determining the effects of morally challenging situations on someone's natural moral licencing, due to the presence of more than one independent variable.

The selection of the recruits appears to be biased by the researchers. They then influenced the recruits to clean; It wasn't a simply do moral good or not. They were pre-obligated by the researcher.

The first demonstration of moral licensing does not click with me and I think I know why. In Germany - or rather in the region I live, we do not give money to beggers, because they are often in groups, pretending to be homeless and then giving the money to the organizer. There is no way of knowing whether they are homeless or not. So instead, sometimes we buy fresh food to go for the beggers and give it to them instead, because firstly, if they are homeless, they have no way of spending the money for drugs or alcohol and secondly, the pretenders always decline the food, since they only need money. I think any homeless person would take warm food anytime.

a good example of such a moral/morally-neutral task would be to either do your own taks that someone gave you or to do it for another person who happens to have to go somewhere else (to the toilet etc.) or to even help that person, because that person is too slow or has a handicap.

I actually have evidence for this "I wouldn't open the door": I worked for three years in a place where people were only allowed in with special permission. There were people at the door multiple times and whenever I saw it, one of these things happened:
· I recognised the person and let them in.
· I made them show me their badge and let them in.
· I asked them who they wanted to visit (which office) and either stood around watching them go there or even went there with them.
· And a few times I actually had to tell someone that I couldn't let them in without either of those conditions matching.

25:55 - Moral reasoning isn't that complicated; & people aren't abandoning their morality here. There isn't enough control over confounding variables.

26:22 - I don't judge these people at all. Yes, it is very easy to engineer situations that pit an individual's personal moralities against one another; that's the essence of a moral dilemma...add a time constraint and push toward a predetermined outcome, yeah, you'll see something, in hindsight, that seems obvious the person acted incorrectly. But the confounding variables are fairly numerous and fairly well recognized, esp the VR theft situation. One major problem...that child actor wasn't believable most of the time. It was an abnormal element so far from normal experience, it's not surprising that confusion or a desire to leave was the common explanation given.

But drop a company authority or some tough guy security guard in there, then it adds a power differential that will suppress many from challenging at that moment... namely, Women and Minorities...cause their risk is inherently greater... If the experiment were repeated, where they are given a 9mm for some reason (?), then the power differential shifts again. Without even drawing the weapon, those w less perceived power, I imagine many more would act in accordance with what we expect. Some, still, it wouldn't be enough; the odds are too stacked against them.

I think that using child to take blame, may be intended to be a more severe moral valuation, clearly is not in this case. First of all, the way the kid jumps up and stays confident in this very stressful situation, despite being a kid, makes others rely on him, he behaves like he knows something and the test subjects, being so confused, just stay with the flow. Second, as the kid is only 12, they tend to believe he will not be in such a trouble, especially when the crime was not that big of a deal. I am not saying, that this gives them a free ticket out of this "immoral" act, but definitely diminishes the weight of the situation in their eyes.
The better experiment I could think about would have been if the kid was confused as well, maybe interacted with the subjects and suggested opening the door. then the security could blame the kid in the first place and he could say nothing, passively agreeing on the deed, (which would have been more natural in this situation, as the child felt blame for suggesting opening the door, and when confronted, could not deny, when in actuality the subject was the one who made the choice)

I really dislike the experiment with the kid taking the fall for the VR equipment being stolen. I feel like that's a poor situation to judge moral licensing. In this kind of uncomfortable social situation where you suddenly realize you did something wrong and there could be consequences for that, the notion of donating a small amount of money to a charity is going to feel irrelevant. It was clear the first girl didn't say anything out of discomfort and fear, and because the kid was so quickly and confidently taking charge of the situation when confronted, while she was still trying to figure out what had happened. I don't think moral licensing had anything to do with her decision to stay quiet. And Zeus could have been pressured to confess because the kid's mom was right there when the kid took the blame, whereas the others who did not confess did not have the mom present. There's also the fact that someone else taking control of a stressful situation can lead to people becoming passive. There were so many other factors at play here, and I feel like the moral licensing from donating to charity took a back seat, especially considering the participants only payed a small amount of money themselves.

One of the problem with the final experiment is that the kid jumps right away and says he opened the door.
1.The kid and his mom were in the room before the subject arrived.

(the subject could have thought that the kid opened the door earlier and he was confessing for that, because the guy that just came in looked like a regular worker)
2.The thief did not look suspicious, as the subject say "I thought he worked here" 22:50.
(so it will take a couple of seconds to realize that the guy that just came in is the guy they talk about)


The subject did not had time to understand the situation.
He did't had time to react because he was still puzzled/surprised by the kids confession.
(although, if the subject had time to confess before the kid, the experiment would not work) (so the kid confession thing had to be quick, but it creates confusion and it distorts the experiment)


The subject that confessed, it took him about 6 seconds to realize that the kid was taking the blame 22:40.

I think the whole idea of moral licensing is completely questionable. I find it absurd to generalize the actions people choose to do based on previous "moral" actions. Each person has their own reasoning when they choose to or not to do an action and to say it's based off of a simple hypothesis is unlike Micheal. Micheal and the other researcher also went into each situation with a very clear bias and tried to apply their beliefs to each situation, like 21:27. We will never truly know the intention behind a person's action, and it is unreasonable to assume through limited testing. The experiment with the VR and kid definitely say something telling about morality, but I just think the analysis and application of it to moral licensing was irresponsible.

This experiment design is really silly. Equating giving money to a homeless man to picking up trash? These are completely different things. One is impersonal, the other personal; one objectively benevolent, the other questionable based on how you feel about the act of begging and how you judge the person asking you for money. What if it was kind-eyed middle aged woman with three kids asking for money? What if it was a rummy derelict who scratched his crotch & ogled the girls as they walked by? As soon as you introduce an individual to this equation, reasonable controls go out the window, because each subject has his or her own innate biases and contexts. It wasn't that incredibly difficult to come up with equivalent moral acts and yet somehow they didn't even bother. Just sloppy! A very lazy test that would get a failing grade in any self-respecting high school social science class. Do better, guys.

While moral licencing could very well be a real thing, I think this experiment didn't do a good job of testing it. The scenes that were set were less real than what you would go through in real life. The first one went well enough, but the way they went about having the homeless man show up was strange. The second one was way out of the norm. The scene starts with then in a room where they don't know each other well, which is normal of course. The man shows up and asks to be let in and they let him in, can see why that might happen. He leaves with the box and the subjects sit down, again, I can see why that would happen. But then when they ask where the box was, the kid answers immediately. There was no pause, no initial time for it to sink in. The kid answers immediately that he did it. This scrambles the subjects mind because they don't know what to do or why this kid is so ready to take the blame. The subject Michael did indeed say that he let them in but it fell on deaf ears, this possibly made him feel discouraged from mentioning it again because of how tense he felt saying it the first time. You can tell he does not feel comfortable, not knowing exactly what the repercussions would be. A better way of going about the second experiment would be that they question the kid first, accusing him. Letting the thought sink in and then seeing if they act. With how tense the air gets, a lot of people choke. Like I said, maybe I'm wrong and these findings are correct, but it just felt poorly executed.

In my opinion, both experiments have way too many variables, and thus can't measure or provide solid support for the Moral License theory.

In the first experiment:
There are many different attitudes towards cleaning the park and towards giving money to the homeless. E.g. Subject has OCD, or wanting to socialize, feeling tired, not trusting the homeless, actually needing all the money, and so.
The point is, we can't assume the subjects choices were only based on 'Moral License'.


In the second experiment:
The subjects are just too overwhelmed with the event sequences - New environment, being introduced to a child, sit in quiet black and isolated room, constant aggressive banging on the door, child taking blame (which is very confusing), the escalation of the seriousness of the situation (boss walks in, security walks in). Heck, that's mentally paralyzing.

In my opinion (Note: I am still a high-school student, and barely able to legally get a driver's license meaning or drink alcohol.) I think a lot of the participant's reactions in the last test were more-plausible than I would've thought, and a lot goes of it is from the fact that it was a child that was there.
A child has generally less consequences than what those participants, legal adults, would have had if they themselves confessed. To them in that moment it was a real and active situation, and they were rationalizing whether or not they should confess instead of letting the child be reprimanded instead of them. (Though that is assuming they even would get remorse from letting a child be wrongly-reprimanded.)
To them, they rationalized it by the fact that if they confessed they would've gotten a larger consequence, and to those who had donated money, they felt that their decision had been more-justified, because they had done a "good deed" and have already done something out of their "kindness", being $1-$10(Seen as $100-$1000) and therefore the possible consequences of the situation, and the outcome of them not being blamed, were quite justified. The first one was already a rational-enough justification, and even more so for having donated money.


Personally, I felt the situation would drastically have changed if it wasn't a child, if it was indeed an adult, still an actor of course, and still had to admit they they did it even if they didn't, the situation would vary a lot, but it wouldn't have been the same as if it were a kid and also a parent. Let's say you let the guy in, and like any other participant, you currently might not have much remorse as to what you just did, (To be honest, being that it was basically right after or a few minutes after the woman who was like organizing or something left, the abrupt chances of a perfectly-placed man going into the room, saying He is carrying a load of stuff so He couldn't open the door is quite suspicious even as a viewer who already knows that He is stealing stuff instead of being an authorized person.)
Then the woman comes in and makes sure no one unauthorized went in because there clearly are many things missing, notably the VR experience thingies.The other person, let's say it's your average run-of-the-mill Steven David, white dude, normal build, He's a decent person, He doesn't look like He stands out, and He's just here for the VR experience and donated, probably works around the near vicinity, basically the same as you. When the woman starts asking, Steven looks at you but then looks like He will hesitate, but then speaks up and takes the blame, you feeling a bit guilty contribute a bit by trying to explain what happened. Of course because you felt that Steven did what He did to himself and you didn't have much remorse for it at this point, you let him explain that He opened the door, not you.


Now this would feel quite weird, and vastly-different, even if the situation may have been the same, you as the participant would have felt less remorse and less regret and less guilt.
But then the security guard is called in and some other guys come in to inspect the stuff, like in the video, they tell Steven to come outside,of course this isn't a kid and He doesn't have a mom with him, Steven looks at you, then at first hesitates (though still appearing like a normal being hesitating, whether or not it was their crime.) but then gives himself in. How would you feel?
Most-likely you would take more time trying to rationalize and justify your decision to keep shut and not admit that it was you and not Steven. Why? Because the consequences that Steven would get would be much much greater than if it were a child with a parent, but at the same time, you can rationalize it with, "He let himself in, it was his decision."
...Sorry if I tried at first to make it out as if this new version of the situation was going to be vastly-different, but at the end, it ended up being the same thing, except that there was more guilt, but there was also more rationalization. It balances out, and you leave, scot-free. I feel that this displays more into how, the average human being might always try to do this, instead of actually being the most-genuine, they will try their best to get away with what they did, of course, they have moral limits, but they will try to fit in that moral limit as best as they can, and perhaps in extreme cases, try to fit that moral limit into their situation, rather than the opposite way. The more things you do that aren't right and that you aren't aware of the more you do this, the more you try to rationalize what was wrong and make sure that it was right, perhaps you never had the consequences, but the fact you try to rationalize things may be because you are afraid that these consequences will come to bite you back, which in a lot of cases, may happen.

I appreciate the attempts of these experiments but there's a lot of problems here. For the first experiment they even mentioned that a person's habits may have a greater affect. For the second one, the "positive" act in no way is reciprocal to the "negative" one. Does anyone honestly conflate themself donating a dollar to another entity then giving 100x that? If so, they'd need to be excessively narsacistic. The negative being facing possible serious consequences of police involvement and theft where a kid that obviously didn't do it would likely get sorted out. These two scenarios are not similar in intensity. And for both experiments, the way each person was handled, the lines people said, etc varied significantly. and they didn't even mention the possible bias of the kind of person that would respond to such an ad campaign to begin with. This whole episode is a mess.

I don't know if this is good or bad, but I've been conditioned to have a jaded perspective on homeless people asking for money. I know that sounds terrible, but I would rather take them to a store or a fast food joint and buy them their food then to just give them cash. I once encountered a homeless guy at a gas station after work. Now, I had some pizza which I had bought for my team that day. I was taking some of the extra pizza home to have for dinner, so instead of giving him money, I gave him the rest of the pizza. He was genuinely thankful which suggested to me that he really was hungry and not looking to by booze or something. That made me feel good. I had no pizza, but I surely wasn't going to go hungry that night either, unlike that homeless man if he didn't have my pizza.

I'm a little miffed by the first study. There was a danger factor (did the females feel threatened being approached by a man, when they were alone? Are they afraid of pulling out all the money they just got paid and having it stolen?) there is a bias factor (do the people feel a middle aged man could/should be capable of work and not asking for money) and there is also the factor of the other items present. They aren't losing out by giving away other people's things (snacks and sodas) which may have made them feel like they were helping, but also some of those who didn't may not have wanted to give away the things of others. It would have been nice to just give the participants a snack or two and a bottle of water and see if they give them their allotted share, instead of money, and/or told that they were going to have a busy rest of the PSA shoot and to only take one snack/soda. Would those that gave away those things still have given them away, had they thought, this isn't my stuff, and it is carefully being accounted for? If not for that last part, it would have been great to see a couple of people walk through. Are those that give a first person money willing to give a 2nd person a dollar? Are they more willing to give a woman a dollar instead of a man? It could have been done a little more broadly and still portrayed in a single episode and left the 'letting the kid take the fall' to another study or a continuation of the study.

The first experiment with the PSA is an awful one because it presupposes that there is actual "good" and that not giving a guy some dollars is "bad". They don't mention that they are testing for Christian ethics (altruism). They just say ethics in general as if that's how it is supposed to be no questions asked. It's pretty annoying and absolutely worthless as an experiment because they are not placing the participants' philosophy and context as a factor.

Helping is not good nor is it bad. It's neutral. Good or bad depends on the context of the person. Benevolence is a personality trait. It has nothing to do with morality in and of itself. Pretty horrible part of the episode in my very honest opinion. I did not enjoy it at all. It's almost like this science channel doesn't give philosophy any thought whatsoever :[

The part at 14:00 is way better because it deals with honesty which I regard as important for a variety of reasons and that is tied directly to ethics unlike the previous test which was just based on cultural ethics (which I think are very, very wrong most of the time) but again, sadly, they are using altruism as a prerequisite - the donation part. Why? This is almost infuriating how people take those baseless morals as the standard when doing SCIENTIFIC experiments. First you need to understand ethics. Then you do social experiments around it. You don't just take whatever is given to you and roll with it. Really bad. Again.

The last example has what science tries to avoid to get clear and concise answers: confounding variables. We cannot say definitively that moral licensing was the motivation behind these individuals behavior because there was an element of ambiguity in whether they were astounded that the child is playing the martyr in the first place. So many things wrong with these experiments. For the first one, how do we know people who picked up the trash are not just people who have a philosophy of earning what you get, and people who didn't pick up the trash are more lazily oriented and giving $1 is a low risk high reward. For the second experiment, with the first girl the mother left the room and the girl could have easily thought it was the mom coming back/locked out. Two, just because someone donated $1 doesn't mean they think they filled a moral quota for the day... $1 is a low risk payoff for a reward of feeling positive. If anything it shows people who are willing to accept low risk opportunities to feel good, while not taking high risk opportunities like the situation with the kid. Three, for the guy who fessed up, the mother was in the room, which could have made him feel pressure to admit. None of the sessions shown were repeated under the same circumstances. Experiments with actors like this are always super flawed.


Edit: Also, the girl who didn't open the door gave no donation, which I feel further supports the notion that this experiment is testing peoples compass for risk and reward. Not filling a good deed quota or moral licensing. Also, a kid will get in far less trouble than an adult. Yeah it's still scummy to let the kid take the fall, but again it's a determination of risk and reward.

I think your stolen equipment experiment was flawed. Much like the psychological bias that exists in the morality of giving a homeless person money, I think the morality of letting a child take the blame vs. accepting responsibility could also have been affected because that part of the study felt too similar to the Milgram experiment. I observe that the participants looked conflicted about the fact that Noah was not only willing to take the hit for their violation, he volunteered, and perhaps that made them less likely to want to overrule him. This is similar to the conflict that the Milgram experiment instilled in participants about the morality of advancing a scientific study at the expense of someone's life.

The second experiment had NOTHING, ZERO,  AT ALL, to do with "moral licensing " none.  None of the participants that we were shown followed clear and highly regarded instructions (at least by the mock company) to NOT allow anyone without clearance to gain access to confidential information or to be even opening any doors for anybody for that matter. What this experiment DID show, if not prove, is the participants lack of responsibility, willingness and confidence to follow through with the instructions given and their subjugation to FEAR. ie: opening up the door, not questioning the visitor, or even defaulting to the "I'm not the person who can let you in,man,sorry..."reasoning. Allowing  Noah to take the blame proves that fear and selfishness control and dictate the greater portion of their lives.  I "believe" the aforementioned donation they made only allowed them to sleep at night or boast of their walk on the "high road". Surely there are  examples of "moral licensing " but this test missed its mark.

I'm not convinced that either experiences demonstrated moral licensing. The participants' actions were too easily explained by factors other than the "good deeds" that they did.
A more interesting experiment would have been seeing if test subjects would let an innocent kid take the blame if he had been rude/obnoxious before the event vs a "good" child.

It's difficult to see how the compensation component isn't a confounding variable, in terms of their implicit interpretation of the compensation, in part, being payment for the volluntary work they hadn't expected to have to do. The experimental design could be better, since they were arriving with mindset that they were hired to do paid work. What we see here is revelation of the respective personality differences of the actors. More, some may correlate their doing the voluntary work with their winning positive reputation points with the organizers, and thereby foster more acting work for them in the future.

With the second experiment, participants who don't come forward know that its a child who is taking the blame and, in many people's experience, the consequences for children tend to be a lot less than those for adults. So, letting the child take the blame wouldn't likely be perceived as being as detrimental as their taking the blame. It would be more interesting and more revealing to see the second experiment done when the participant is also a child and/or when both the participant and confederate, both adults, share many characteristics.

Worth noting is the findings of social psychology experiments, even when the experiments are well designed, have been shown to have fading relevance.

Serious flaw. To a lot of us there is a distinct difference in these two scenarios. Personally i would help clean the park and not gove money to the beggar independently of eachother. For starters, the cleaning of the park provides a greater benefit to both the public AND the individual who cannot shoot his PSA until it is clean, combining a moral imperative with self-interest. On the flip side, giving money to the beggar encourages him to continue his vagrancy in that park, as well as having a direct cost to the individual. Asking someone for their money makes them uncomfortable, and sort amounts to slight emotional blackmail. Try this experiment with more consistent scales of morality. Perhaps two different people asking to borrow or use something belonging to the individual, such as their phone. Perhaps while they are waiting to shoot the PSA so time-related concerns can be ruled out.

With the VR demonstration, I feel there may have been an oversight in the demonstration. The thief said his hands were full and his boss wanted him to get things from the room. I love the show but I think both experiments in this episode had too many variables, making it almost inpossible to draw any solid conclusions about whether moral licencing had occurred.

The first experiment was weak because people may have personal reasons for why they may or may not want to pick up trash/give money to a homeless person (which Michael did touch on later). E.g. I'm pretty environmentally conscious and hate litter, so I would help pick up the rubbish. But I have a friend who hates touching litter (even with gloves on) because she has a fear of needles/syringes, so she wouldn't help pick up rubbish. So in that moment, none of us would see picking up rubbish as a "good deed" since our actions benefit us on a personal level.

As for the second experiment, I think it would have been wayyy better if security assumed the kid let the guy in, rather than having the kid confess immediately. I think the kid's confession just confuses the participants and they just think "wait, why is this kid lying? Did I miss something? Maybe I should stay quiet". I mean, the black guy said like 2 times in his recount of the events that he opened the door, but everyone believes the kid when the kid says that he did it. So I imagine the black guy was just really confused about what was going on and chose to stay quiet, not to consciously let the kid take the blame but because he didn't understand what was happening. I think a scenario where blame is assigned to the kid, rather than him standing up and confessing, would have better. E.g. Security comes in and says "Son, did you open the door." "No". "Son, this is serious. Some expensive stuff was stolen and, if you opened the door, you need to tell us". This gives the participant an opportunity to confess. And if they don't, then you can have the kid (reluctantly) say he did it and then go from there.

It’s not that I’m judging them for their decisions. I’m judging them for literally none of them being critical thinkers. They didn’t ask that guy about a badge. They didn’t notice when he was literally stealing. Hell, they didn’t question “hey, don’t you guys have security cameras for this exact reason?”. They didn’t discuss with the kid if they should let the person in. And it just seems weird to me. They sat there in almost dead silence the whole time, awkwardly shifting from the moment they entered the room, until Micheal came in. It’s just odd

I like this experiment but it’s hard for them to weigh the child taking the blame, who would, no doubt, get in waaaaaaaaaay less trouble and not be likely to be jailed, versus a fully grown adult who would possibly, if not likely go to jail for it. It’s still a Yikes situation, but my first instinct is that people are more likely to pass it off to the child who is less likely to get in legal trouble.
Also, I noticed the first one was a woman, and there seemed to be no accounting for the socialization of women to freeze or flight when faced with a situation like that.
Again, it’s not like there were a ton of subjects, but definetly gender has to be considered when there is behavior on the line. I hope in the future when you conduct psychological studies that you factor in socialization.

Personally, when you are contemplating these things such as morality relative to instantaneous decisions, you have to recognize that morality is a long term established role, a goal that takes thi king and analyzing over situations. An adult with moral values is going to take time to assess the situation. None of these adults were given the time to assess the situation.

Furthermore, how one reacts when a child acts out of the norm, such as the child did, one is alarmed that something isnt right. It isnt common for a child to instantly step up and tak the blame. Quick reactions to protect the child or more common that quick reactions of a child to protect an adult. The situation presented actually would confuse participants, making their reactions unpredictable, and more likely to freeze. Why? To gather more data.they see thinking, "what the hell is going on?" Not thinking, "why is this child saying this?"

Because most interactions with children would lead one to not expect a child to do what that child actor did. So, his actions mostlikely alarmed the test subject that something wasn't right, hinted that something else is going on.

Poor test for the results. Too many variables.

Regardless, very interesting and great to watch. But, think about the hidden variables in future experiments.

This experiment is flawed from the very beginning because it is not testing to see if people will do something bad for something good, but rather how much time or energy to someone is willing to put into selfless acts. Since everybody has a limited amount of time and energy, we should expect to see that most people would not do both (especially after putting the effort in to show up for the PSA recording), unless both acts were incredibly trivial, and neither are (or so I think most people would agree, though there's plenty of room for debate on what constitutes "trial acts".)

The first experiment is inherently flawed because it presupposes that the moral thing would have been to give the "homeless" man money, or at least presupposes that the participants perceived that to be the most moral thing to do with the money. In reality, there are valid arguments that the money could have been used more morally. For example, giving it to a charitable organization where that money could go towards providing mosquito nets in an area with high rates of malaria as opposed to giving it to a person the participants might have assumed would have misused the funds. Thus, participants who refused to give the actor money could have been acting according to their moral values and not according to the principle of moral licensing.

I have a lot of problems with the way all of this was set up, but for the sake of brevity I'll focus on how these experiments were built.

The first experiment (as Michael himself put it) didn't really account for variables. People could've had certain preconceptions, stereotypes, and beliefs going into the experiment that would severely impact the results. However, that's to be expected. What's NOT to be expected is for the people making this show to decide that homeless people just casually walk up to people and ask for money. As far as I'm aware, that doesn't happen very often, and when it does happen it usually seems threatening and aggressive. If they had gone for a more passive approach by having the "homeless person" laying down with a sign and a box across from the tent, the results might've been drastically different. Also of note is that one of the participants had his newly-earned money IN HIS HANDS when the man walked up to him, which might've skewed his reaction to the request since he doesn't have to commit much to giving. I would posit that there's a lot of thought that goes into taking your wallet out in front of random stranger asking for money, and that many can't get past that initial hurdle and deflect the request with an excuse. But if you already have all of your money out in the open, most of that thought process doesn't happen, so you might feel more generous due to how simple the act becomes.

Then there's the second experiment. This was hands down the WORST built experiment I've ever seen in a serious context (i.e. not "social experimenters"). The very idea that the average human being would react casually to a CHILD taking the blame for letting a thief into a VR studio is utterly ridiculous. Everything around the child's actions is completely wrong and unnatural(though not necessarily because of the child actor), and leaves the participants more confused than anything. I'm pretty sure the first participant shown was having an existential crisis the whole time, which led to her "freezing up", as she put it. Without any context or reasoning to attribute to the child's actions, the participants are left in a very uncomfortable situation that bypasses morality entirely because of how ludicrous it all is. Instead of trying to make a difficult moral choice, they're instead busy grappling with reality of what's happening around them. What's baffling to me is how Michael can keep a straight face throughout the whole charade, which I can only chalk up to numbness after having seen enough rehearsals. More than anything, this experiment showcases how unreliable these post-experiment "debriefings" are, since there's always the possibility (especially here) that the participants could be lying to try and get out of there faster, or because they haven't had enough time to process what just happened and don't want to just sit there awkwardly for 5-10 minutes while they think of a good, honest answer.

Both experiments are invalid, but the second one is so terrible in execution that it could only be used as an example of what NOT to do in future experiments. Really disappointing stuff here, hoping for better in this season and the (possible) next.

i feel like there are better ways to test this, these experiments make too many assumptions and at least some of the variables could have been controlled better.

The application of morality is subjective,.
What the tester is designing to be a 'moral good choice' or a 'moral bad choice" may not be what the subjects would think is "good" or "bad'.
with the first experiment they conducted it was clear previous experience had marked their associations with homelessness, and that's just the thing! previous experiences will always dictate how a person assesses a situation and it may be different from what the tester was counting on being 'the good moral choice' and 'the bad moral choice'. thus we don't actually get a clear idea of whether or not they were psychologically excusing themselves from making a good moral decision because of previous morally good decisions.

I think they would need to re-design an experiment where you have already gotten some direct assessment about what the subject believes to be moral behavior. some people think rules should be a followed to a tee, others think they're guidelines that you don't go out of your way to break but there's nothing inherently wrong with breaking one. some people think giving money to homeless people helps them get food and help them in a tough situation, others are distrustful and think the homeless person might spend the money on drugs and thus the better thing to do is not to enable. some people think it is important to be honest in all things even if it is painful, some people think it is better to lie or conceal an idea if it means avoiding someone's pain.

one you have pre-screened the subject matter and the subjects so you have a reasonable idea of at least how the subjects themselves would think they would behave when acting morally, you'd need a control group of people. these people would not have the "moral good choice" like the other group but still get the chance to make a "moral bad choice". Then you could compare the numbers of people who did the 'moral bad choice" in the group who had done something "morally good' versus the people who didn't and see if there's a noticeable trend.
maybe when you do something good it actually makes us feel like we're good people and we're more likely to do more good things? or perhaps both this and moral licensing are true to varying degrees.

Hi

Social psychology studies are sometimes really hard when it comes to proving cause and effect. You can only control a limited number of factors.

Some possible flaws or factors leading to deficits in the first study might have been:

1. Having two tests that aren't equivalent to each other and don't take into account outside factors. For example there is a stigma around homeless people spending money on drugs and around them as people in general that isn't present with picking up trash, to have them be in the same group of equivalency to test moral relativism is more like testing two TYPES of moral relativism that are character-dependent
2. Not really having any control groups. Also lack of diversification in displaying what participants chose, I don't know if there were any participants who for example didn't donate and didn't help the homeless man but did clean up, and it's likely there were some.
3. Behavior traits inherent in participants that would have contributed to their choices other than their morality. People like the vlogger might have been more inclined to donate or help the homeless man or donate than clean up trash because it's simply less work.

Possible flaws in the second study might have been:

1. Not making all aspects of the situation entirely clear to the participant. When many people picture a thief they have a specific image in mind, they physically might have not registered that the man who took the VR set wasn't just some worker that forgot his key card, his attitude was pretty casual and his demeanor seemed calm which is contrary to what most people assume of thieves.
2. Making the actor be a child. This goes along with point number one. Adults seemingly have more credibility, and if a child claims responsibility for an action that they didn't commit it is more likely that the adult involved will just think they're being silly, imagining things, and not think it important enough to correct the child because of the assumption of misunderstanding.
3. Fight or flight response/ anxieties/ social deficits. When just told no one should knock on a door, someone does, and then after letting them in you are told they are a thief and security and staff start interrogating you, that is sufficient ground for anyone to freeze up, even if they want to do the right thing. Regardless of how much you donated beforehand, your individual response to stress is going to be a huge factor here. People who are shy or timid but who are "morally righteous" will have different responses than those with the opposite behavioral pattern.

TL:DR It's true moral relativism doesn't define whether you're a good person or not, but it also can't be defined by the most recent actions you took. Otherwise there would be no one in the first study that donated, helped, and cleaned, for example. Socialization and character traits of an individual are huge factors, along with the type of situation they're in. Moral relativism might be an aspect in the behavior we've seen today, but it certainly doesn't tell the whole story.

I disagree with the process of this experiment. When I look at trash in an otherwise beautiful garden, I automatically think," oh shit it would be very moral of me to clean this". But when I see a homeless person asking for money, i dont think that. rather i think, "It would be morally wrong for me to give that person money". I come from india and I can tell you that there are atleast 5 times more people asking for money. usually, the only beggars I give money or food to are women and children, someone who otherwise would find it hard to find a job for legal or cultural reasons. But when i see a fit adult man asking for money, it is always morally wrong because the asking never stops. You could give a beggar a thousand dollars and he would be begging the next month you see him. Because thats sort of what he is best at. So according to this, it can be seen that a few people dont count the donation of money as a necessarily good deed.
Sure you can make the argument that the homeless person was infact a war veteran, but i would contend that its better to either give them food, or donate to a homeless shelter or political party aiming at helping homeless people. If you give money to a homeless person, you are mostly doing it because you want to feel good about yourself. And that's totally fine, but not everyone feels this way. Hence, this experiment might be hugely biased.

I always ask if they've eaten recently, if they've had a shower recently, and if they would like to do their laundry. If it's cold, I might offer them the couch- for one night only.

If they answer no to the first two, I offer to fix those two issues. If they want to do laundry and watch some tv, they're more than welcome to. If they'd like a place to sleep for the night, my couch is their couch- again, for one night only.

And no, I don't believe I'm putting my wife or myself in danger. But if I'm wrong, we have three beefy dogs that would happily teach someone what danger means, if my wife or I are attacked. Homeless dude could maybe, MAYBE stealth kill one of them before the other two woke up and ended him.

Lastly- do any of you who are saying "homeless people did this to themselves" or "they'll just buy drugs and booze" know what it's like to ACTUALLY try to break the cold wind by covering up with random bits of trash? Or to feel so hungry you honestly think you could be dead before you wake up in the morning? Or feel the skin separating in the areas where you haven't been able to clean the dirt and sweat and grime of the fabulously rich homeless life have piled up and started to exfoliate your healthy skin away?

Have you ever been so depressed from being homeless, alone, hungry, terrified you could be killed randomly by some fucked up kids, whose parents taught them homeless people aren't real people, saying ignorant shit like "gross! ignore them and walk away Chadrick!" So depressed because of all this that you think about literally EVERY decision you've ever made and how, if you had another chance, you'd do it all differently- or maybe that you would give away half of China just to have someone sit down and ask how you're doing today...

Most people absolutely DID put themselves into homelessness, if that I can be sure since I've never heard a news story about someone going around and forcing people to be homeless at gunpoint... What a fucking stupid thing to say.

And some homeless people definitely ARE going to just go buy drugs and booze. Because some seriously fuckin weird people APPARENTLY don't think being homeless is awesome, I guess.

And so what if they did it to themselves or do drugs and drink? If they were as awful as you people think, they'd just beat the shit out of you and steal it. Hell, I'm almost wishing I could do that, and I'm not even homeless anymore.

But let's say for the sake of argument that they're just terrible people who are respectfully and politely asking you for spare change-

they're still. fucking. people.

So why not just politely and respectfully say no, if helping feed the hungry, or clothe the naked, or shelter the homeless isn't your bag? And look, I get it... Jesus did all those things and look what he got... Crucified!

The first experiment is based solely in moral relativism. The second one possibly is as well as we are lead to understand that there is a link between the act of donating and the actions.

To understand true morality, one needs to first understand what is right and what is wrong.

A right is an action that does no harm to another human being. Thus when something is right, it is moral.

Looking at the first experiment with the correct information, we can see that:

1. Choosing to pick up the trash or not is moral
2. Choosing to donate that which you earned to another, or not, is moral
3. Choosing to give away something that does not belong to you is theft and is immoral

Looking at the second experiment with the correct information, we can see that:

1. Choosing to open the door enables the theft of property is immoral
2. Choosing to not speak up on your actions that causes blame to be shifted to the child is immoral

I'm not sure how the moral "weight" of picking up litter compares to helping the homeless for each of the subjects, to say nothing about other competing moral balancing factors going on with the subjects' lives outside of the experiment. Unless the subjects have been heavily screened to gauge how morally upstanding they consider themselves to be normally, who's to say whether any one of them could have made a donation or cut someone off in traffic on the way in to film that day? A lot of uncontrollable variables in this experiment, which makes this feel like not very good science.
